news-item.title: MCA to ascertain whether FTIL as holding co violated norms
news-item.text: New Delhi: The Ministry of Corporate Affairs is looking to ascertain whether Jignesh Shahled Financial Technologies violated laws, especially with respect to carrying out its duties as a holding company, reports PTI. Financial Technologies (India) Ltd (FTIL) is the flagship company of Shah Group, whose firm National Spot Exchange Ltd (NSEL) is grappling with a Rs 5,600 crore payment crisis.Besides these entities, the continuing crisis has also sparked off a series of regulatory interventions that has thrown spotlight on the group's various other ventures, including MCX, MCXSX and IEX.Sources said the Ministry is looking at whether FTIL as a holding company mismanaged the affairs of the subsidiary. The Ministry has found "gross violations" by FTIL board on corporate governance matters, among others.Although the Ministry has completed its report on FTIL, it has sought views of the Law Ministry and other agencies before taking a final call.Earlier this month, the capital market regulator Sebi ruled that FTIL is not a "fit and proper person to acquire or hold any equity share or any instrument that provides for entitlement for equity shares or rights over equity shares at any future date, in a recognised stock exchange or clearing corporation."The order would be applicable for both direct and indirect holdings of FTIL in stock exchanges and clearing corporations. Meanwhile, a probe of NSEL books by the Ministry had found that the exchange's board failed to perform its duties towards shareholders, in breach of regulations.The interim report of inspection, carried out by the Registrar of Companies (RoC), Mumbai, had found corporate governance failure at multiple levels, including lack of transparency, integrity, compliance and ethics.
